natural problem: A book with 53 pages numbered 1 to 53 has its pages renumbered in reverse, from 53 to 1. For how many pages do the new page number and old page number share the same units digit?
natural solution: Each page is assigned two numbers.

We can generalize the numbers assigned to page $x$ to be the pair $x$ and $54-x$ for $1 \leq x \leq 53$. That is, if $x = 1$, then we can see that page number one is assigned the numbers $1$ and $54-1 = 53$.
It is fairly easy to see that the units digits of $x$ and $54-x$ will only be the same if $x$ has a units digit of $2$ or a units digit of $7$.
Thus, we simply must count how many such $x$ there are between $1$ and $54$. Possibilities for $x$ are: 2, 7, 12, 17, 22, 27, 32, 37, 42, 47, and 52.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes old_num new_num :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. old_num n = n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. new_num n = 54 - n"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> (old_num n mod 10 = new_num n mod 10)"
shows  "card {n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53 \<and> old_num n mod 10 = new_num n mod 10} = 11"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A book with 53 pages numbered 1 to 53 has its pages renumbered in reverse, from 53 to 1. For how many pages do the new page number and old page number share the same units digit? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Each page is assigned two numbers.
 We can generalize the numbers assigned to page $x$ to be the pair $x$ and $54-x$ for $1 \leq x \leq 53$. That is, if $x = 1$, then we can see that page number one is assigned the numbers $1$ and $54-1 = 53$.
 It is fairly easy to see that the units digits of $x$ and $54-x$ will only be the same if $x$ has a units digit of $2$ or a units digit of $7$.
 Thus, we simply must count how many such $x$ there are between $1$ and $54$. Possibilities for $x$ are: 2, 7, 12, 17, 22, 27, 32, 37, 42, 47, and 52.
 Therefore, there are $\boxed{11}$ such pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes old_num new_num :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. old_num n = n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. new_num n = 54 - n"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> (old_num n mod 10 = new_num n mod 10)"
shows  "card {n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53 \<and> old_num n mod 10 = new_num n mod 10} = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Consider two integer functions: the first one, old_num, returns the number itself, while the second one, new_num, returns 54 minus the number. For all numbers from 1 to 53 inclusive, the last digit (the remainder after division by 10) of the number and 54 minus the number are the same. How many such numbers exist? The final answer is 11.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "p 1 = 53"
and h1 : "p 53 = 1"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 2 \<and> n \<le> 52 \<longrightarrow> p n = p (n-1) - 1"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> n mod 10 = p n mod 10"
shows  "card {n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53 \<and> n mod 10 = p n mod 10} = 11"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A book with 53 pages numbered 1 to 53 has its pages renumbered in reverse, from 53 to 1. For how many pages do the new page number and old page number share the same units digit? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Each page is assigned two numbers.
 We can generalize the numbers assigned to page $x$ to be the pair $x$ and $54-x$ for $1 \leq x \leq 53$. That is, if $x = 1$, then we can see that page number one is assigned the numbers $1$ and $54-1 = 53$.
 It is fairly easy to see that the units digits of $x$ and $54-x$ will only be the same if $x$ has a units digit of $2$ or a units digit of $7$.
 Thus, we simply must count how many such $x$ there are between $1$ and $54$. Possibilities for $x$ are: 2, 7, 12, 17, 22, 27, 32, 37, 42, 47, and 52.
 Therefore, there are $\boxed{11}$ such pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "p 1 = 53"
and h1 : "p 53 = 1"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 2 \<and> n \<le> 52 \<longrightarrow> p n = p (n-1) - 1"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> n mod 10 = p n mod 10"
shows  "card {n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53 \<and> n mod 10 = p n mod 10} = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A function $p$ is defined on the natural numbers as follows: $p(1)=53$, $p(53)=1$, and for all $2\leq n\leq 52$, $p(n)=p(n-1)-1$. Furthermore, for all $1\leq n\leq 53$, the remainder when $n$ is divided by $10$ is the same as the remainder when $p(n)$ is divided by $10$. How many numbers between $1$ and $53$ (inclusive) have the property that the remainder when they are divided by $10$ is the same as the remainder when $p(n)$ is divided by $10$? The final Answer is $11$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes page :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> page n = 53 - n + 1"
shows  "card {n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53 \<and> n mod 10 = page n mod 10} = 11"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A book with 53 pages numbered 1 to 53 has its pages renumbered in reverse, from 53 to 1. For how many pages do the new page number and old page number share the same units digit? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Each page is assigned two numbers.
 We can generalize the numbers assigned to page $x$ to be the pair $x$ and $54-x$ for $1 \leq x \leq 53$. That is, if $x = 1$, then we can see that page number one is assigned the numbers $1$ and $54-1 = 53$.
 It is fairly easy to see that the units digits of $x$ and $54-x$ will only be the same if $x$ has a units digit of $2$ or a units digit of $7$.
 Thus, we simply must count how many such $x$ there are between $1$ and $54$. Possibilities for $x$ are: 2, 7, 12, 17, 22, 27, 32, 37, 42, 47, and 52.
 Therefore, there are $\boxed{11}$ such pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes page :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> page n = 53 - n + 1"
shows  "card {n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53 \<and> n mod 10 = page n mod 10} = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: A book has 53 pages numbered from 1 to 53. The page numbers are reversed in the book, so that page 1 shows 53 and page 53 shows 1. How many page numbers have the same last digit when read normally and in reverse? The final answer is 11.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes pages :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> pages i = 53 - i + 1"
shows  "card {i. i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> 53 \<and> i mod 10 = pages i mod 10} = 11"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A book with 53 pages numbered 1 to 53 has its pages renumbered in reverse, from 53 to 1. For how many pages do the new page number and old page number share the same units digit? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Each page is assigned two numbers.
 We can generalize the numbers assigned to page $x$ to be the pair $x$ and $54-x$ for $1 \leq x \leq 53$. That is, if $x = 1$, then we can see that page number one is assigned the numbers $1$ and $54-1 = 53$.
 It is fairly easy to see that the units digits of $x$ and $54-x$ will only be the same if $x$ has a units digit of $2$ or a units digit of $7$.
 Thus, we simply must count how many such $x$ there are between $1$ and $54$. Possibilities for $x$ are: 2, 7, 12, 17, 22, 27, 32, 37, 42, 47, and 52.
 Therefore, there are $\boxed{11}$ such pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes pages :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> pages i = 53 - i + 1"
shows  "card {i. i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> 53 \<and> i mod 10 = pages i mod 10} = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Consider a book with 53 pages. Each page number is transformed by a function that returns 53 minus the page number plus 1. How many page numbers are there such that, when the page number is divided by 10, the remainder is the same as the remainder when the transformed page number is divided by 10? The final answer is 11.

theorem
fixes old_number new_number :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. old_number n = n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. new_number n = 54 - n"
shows  "card {n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53 \<and> old_number n mod 10 = new_number n mod 10} = 11"
a_4.formal solution:

 We can generalize the numbers assigned to page $x$ to be the pair $x$ and $54-x$ for $1 \leq x \leq 53$. That is, if $x = 1$, then we can see that page number one is assigned the numbers $1$ and $54-1 = 53$.

theorem
fixes old_number new_number :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find how many numbers between 1 and 53 inclusive have the same remainder when divided by 10 as the number obtained by subtracting that same number from 54. The final answer is 11.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> f x = x"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> g x = 54 - x"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> f x mod 10 = g x mod 10"
shows  "card {x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 53 \<and> f x mod 10 = g x mod 10} = 11"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A book with 53 pages numbered 1 to 53 has its pages renumbered in reverse, from 53 to 1. For how many pages do the new page number and old page number share the same units digit? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Each page is assigned two numbers.
 We can generalize the numbers assigned to page $x$ to be the pair $x$ and $54-x$ for $1 \leq x \leq 53$. That is, if $x = 1$, then we can see that page number one is assigned the numbers $1$ and $54-1 = 53$.
 It is fairly easy to see that the units digits of $x$ and $54-x$ will only be the same if $x$ has a units digit of $2$ or a units digit of $7$.
 Thus, we simply must count how many such $x$ there are between $1$ and $54$. Possibilities for $x$ are: 2, 7, 12, 17, 22, 27, 32, 37, 42, 47, and 52.
 Therefore, there are $\boxed{11}$ such pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes f g :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> f x = x"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> g x = 54 - x"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> f x mod 10 = g x mod 10"
shows  "card {x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 53 \<and> f x mod 10 = g x mod 10} = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Let's define two functions $f(x) = x$ and $g(x) = 54 - x$ for all integers $x$ between 1 and 53 inclusive. How many integers $x$ between 1 and 53 inclusive satisfy the condition that $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ have the same remainder when divided by 10? The final answer is 11.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> f n = 54 - n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> n mod 10 = f n mod 10"
shows  "card {n. n \<le> 53 \<and> n mod 10 = f n mod 10} = 11"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A book with 53 pages numbered 1 to 53 has its pages renumbered in reverse, from 53 to 1. For how many pages do the new page number and old page number share the same units digit? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Each page is assigned two numbers.
 We can generalize the numbers assigned to page $x$ to be the pair $x$ and $54-x$ for $1 \leq x \leq 53$. That is, if $x = 1$, then we can see that page number one is assigned the numbers $1$ and $54-1 = 53$.
 It is fairly easy to see that the units digits of $x$ and $54-x$ will only be the same if $x$ has a units digit of $2$ or a units digit of $7$.
 Thus, we simply must count how many such $x$ there are between $1$ and $54$. Possibilities for $x$ are: 2, 7, 12, 17, 22, 27, 32, 37, 42, 47, and 52.
 Therefore, there are $\boxed{11}$ such pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> f n = 54 - n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> n mod 10 = f n mod 10"
shows  "card {n. n \<le> 53 \<and> n mod 10 = f n mod 10} = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: For a function $f$ defined such that for all natural numbers $n$ less than or equal to 53, $f(n) = 54 - n$, and for these $n$, the remainder when $n$ is divided by 10 equals the remainder when $f(n)$ is divided by 10, find the number of such $n$. The final answer is 11.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes old_number new_number :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..53} \<longrightarrow> old_number n = n"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..53} \<longrightarrow> new_number n = 54 - n"
shows  "card {n \<in> {1..53}. old_number n mod 10 = new_number n mod 10} = 11"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A book with 53 pages numbered 1 to 53 has its pages renumbered in reverse, from 53 to 1. For how many pages do the new page number and old page number share the same units digit? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Each page is assigned two numbers.
 We can generalize the numbers assigned to page $x$ to be the pair $x$ and $54-x$ for $1 \leq x \leq 53$. That is, if $x = 1$, then we can see that page number one is assigned the numbers $1$ and $54-1 = 53$.
 It is fairly easy to see that the units digits of $x$ and $54-x$ will only be the same if $x$ has a units digit of $2$ or a units digit of $7$.
 Thus, we simply must count how many such $x$ there are between $1$ and $54$. Possibilities for $x$ are: 2, 7, 12, 17, 22, 27, 32, 37, 42, 47, and 52.
 Therefore, there are $\boxed{11}$ such pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes old_number new_number :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..53} \<longrightarrow> old_number n = n"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..53} \<longrightarrow> new_number n = 54 - n"
shows  "card {n \<in> {1..53}. old_number n mod 10 = new_number n mod 10} = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Consider two functions old_number and new_number that map each of the numbers from 1 to 53 to themselves and 54 minus themselves, respectively. How many numbers are there from 1 to 53 such that the remainder when old_number and new_number are divided by 10 is the same? The final answer is 11.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes old_number new_number :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> old_number n = n"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> new_number n = 54 - n"
and h2 : "card {n. old_number n mod 10 = new_number n mod 10 \<and> n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53} = k"
shows  "k = 11"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A book with 53 pages numbered 1 to 53 has its pages renumbered in reverse, from 53 to 1. For how many pages do the new page number and old page number share the same units digit? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Each page is assigned two numbers.
 We can generalize the numbers assigned to page $x$ to be the pair $x$ and $54-x$ for $1 \leq x \leq 53$. That is, if $x = 1$, then we can see that page number one is assigned the numbers $1$ and $54-1 = 53$.
 It is fairly easy to see that the units digits of $x$ and $54-x$ will only be the same if $x$ has a units digit of $2$ or a units digit of $7$.
 Thus, we simply must count how many such $x$ there are between $1$ and $54$. Possibilities for $x$ are: 2, 7, 12, 17, 22, 27, 32, 37, 42, 47, and 52.
 Therefore, there are $\boxed{11}$ such pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes old_number new_number :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> old_number n = n"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53 \<longrightarrow> new_number n = 54 - n"
and h2 : "card {n. old_number n mod 10 = new_number n mod 10 \<and> n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 53} = k"
shows  "k = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem:
Consider two sequences of integers. The first sequence, called old_number, contains all the integers from 1 to 53. The second sequence, called new_number, contains all the integers from 53 to 1 in reverse order.

How many numbers from 1 to 53 have the same remainder when divided by 10 in both sequences? The final answer is 11.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_pages :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_pages = 53"
shows  "card {i. i \<in> {1..num_pages} \<and> (i mod 10 = (num_pages + 1 - i) mod 10)} = 11"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A book with 53 pages numbered 1 to 53 has its pages renumbered in reverse, from 53 to 1. For how many pages do the new page number and old page number share the same units digit? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Each page is assigned two numbers.
 We can generalize the numbers assigned to page $x$ to be the pair $x$ and $54-x$ for $1 \leq x \leq 53$. That is, if $x = 1$, then we can see that page number one is assigned the numbers $1$ and $54-1 = 53$.
 It is fairly easy to see that the units digits of $x$ and $54-x$ will only be the same if $x$ has a units digit of $2$ or a units digit of $7$.
 Thus, we simply must count how many such $x$ there are between $1$ and $54$. Possibilities for $x$ are: 2, 7, 12, 17, 22, 27, 32, 37, 42, 47, and 52.
 Therefore, there are $\boxed{11}$ such pages.
 *)

theorem
fixes num_pages :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_pages = 53"
shows  "card {i. i \<in> {1..num_pages} \<and> (i mod 10 = (num_pages + 1 - i) mod 10)} = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Count the number of pages in a 53-page book such that the page number's remainder when divided by 10 is the same as the remainder when the total number of pages plus 1, minus the page number, is divided by 10. The final answer is 11.
